revealed_symptoms.color variation: It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.
revealed_symptoms.shiny or waxy bump: It looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.

hidden_symptoms.hyperkeratosis: There's this rough, flaky spot that won’t go away, and sometimes it peels.
hidden_symptoms.pruritus: It’s super itchy sometimes, or feels kind of tingly, like a weird sensation under my skin.
hidden_symptoms.asymmetry: One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven.
hidden_symptoms.evolving: This thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
hidden_symptoms.border irregularity: The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles.
hidden_symptoms.telangiectasia: There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before.
hidden_symptoms.ulceration: It’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back.
hidden_symptoms.rapid growth: I swear this mole or bump got bigger really fast, like in just a few weeks.
hidden_symptoms.induration: It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there.
hidden_symptoms.nodule formation: It’s kind of thick or raised, not flat like some of my other moles.

patient_history.content: Hi, I'll be your doctor today. What brings you in?

Well, I have this thing on my skin. It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in. Also, it looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.

Thank you for the information. I understand you have a skin lesion that appears to be multi-colored and persistent. To better understand this, could you tell me when you first noticed this skin lesion?
I’m not really sure when I first noticed it, but it’s been there for a while now.

Thank you. Since you've had it for a while, has the skin lesion changed in size, shape, or color since you first noticed it? Also, do you experience any itching, pain, or bleeding from the skin lesion?
Yes, this thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
Thank you. The fact that the lesion is changing is a concern. Do you experience any itching, pain, or bleeding from the skin lesion? Also, is there any family history of skin cancer?
It’s super itchy sometimes, or feels kind of tingly, like a weird sensation under my skin.
Thank you. The itching and tingling are important details. Regarding family history, is there anyone in your family who has had skin cancer?
I don’t know. I’ve never asked.
Thank you. To help me understand this further, can you tell me where on your body the skin lesion is located?
It’s on my skin, but I'd rather not say exactly where.

I understand. Based on your description of a changing, multi-colored, and itchy skin lesion, I am concerned it could be an atypical nevus, or even potentially melanoma. It is important to get this looked at by a dermatologist. If you are comfortable, I recommend a biopsy. Would you be open to that?
I’m not sure what that means. Can you explain?

Of course. A biopsy is a simple procedure where a small sample of the skin lesion is taken and sent to a lab for analysis. This helps us determine what is causing the changes you've described and whether there are any abnormal cells. This is the best way to know for sure what is going on and to provide appropriate treatment. Would you be open to this?
Sure, I guess I could do that.

doctor_history.content: Well, I have this thing on my skin. It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in. Also, it looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.
